input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0000623', '0000623', '0000179', '0000179'], 'document_source': ['GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR'], 'document_url': ['https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/mandibulofacial-dysostosis-with-microcephaly', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/mandibulofacial-dysostosis-with-microcephaly', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/cholesteryl-ester-storage-disease', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/cholesteryl-ester-storage-disease'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C0013393|C1864652', 'C0013393|C1864652', 'C0008384', 'C0008384'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T047', 'T047', 'T047', 'T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ['mandibulofacial dysostosis, Guion-Almeida type|MFDGA|MFDM', 'mandibulofacial dysostosis, Guion-Almeida type|MFDGA|MFDM', 'CESD|cholesterol ester hydrolase deficiency|cholesterol ester storage disease|LAL deficiency|LIPA deficiency|lysosomal acid lipase deficiency', 'CESD|cholesterol ester hydrolase deficiency|cholesterol ester storage disease|LAL deficiency|LIPA deficiency|lysosomal acid lipase deficiency'], 'question_id': ['0000623-4', '0000623-5', '0000179-1', '0000179-2'], 'question_focus': ['mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly', 'mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly', 'cholesteryl ester storage disease', 'cholesteryl ester storage disease'], 'question_type': ['inheritance', 'treatment', 'information', 'frequency'], 'question': ['Is mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly inherited ?', 'What are the treatments for mandibulofacial dysostosis with microcephaly ?', 'What is (are) cholesteryl ester storage disease ?', 'How many people are affected by cholesteryl ester storage disease ?'], 'answer': ['This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the disorder. Most cases result from new mutations in the gene and occur in people with no history of the disorder in their family. In other cases, an affected person inherits the mutation from a parent. The parent may be mildly affected or may be unaffected. Sometimes the parent has the gene mutation only in some or all of their sperm or egg cells, which is known as germline mosaicism. In these cases, the parent has no signs or symptoms of the condition.', 'These resources address the diagnosis or management of MFDM:  - Gene Review: Gene Review: Mandibulofacial Dysostosis with Microcephaly  - Genetic Testing Registry: Growth and mental retardation, mandibulofacial dysostosis, microcephaly, and cleft palate   These resources from MedlinePlus offer information about the diagnosis and management of various health conditions:  - Diagnostic Tests  - Drug Therapy  - Surgery and Rehabilitation  - Genetic Counseling   - Palliative Care', 'Cholesteryl ester storage disease is a rare inherited condition involving the breakdown and use of fats and cholesterol in the body (lipid metabolism). In affected individuals, harmful amounts of lipids accumulate in cells and tissues throughout the body. The liver is most severely affected. An enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is one of the key signs of the disease. In addition, chronic liver disease (cirrhosis) can develop. An accumulation of fatty deposits on the artery walls (atherosclerosis) is usually seen early in life. The deposits narrow the arteries and can eventually block them, increasing the chance of having a heart attack or stroke.  The symptoms of cholesteryl ester storage disease are highly variable. Some people have such mild symptoms that they go undiagnosed until late adulthood, while others can have liver dysfunction in early childhood. The expected lifespan of those with cholesteryl ester storage disease depends on the severity of the associated complications.', 'Cholesteryl ester storage disease appears to be a rare disorder. About 50 individuals affected by this condition have been reported worldwide.']}
